mods.abstract: Physical hardships in the mountains are usually preferred by the highlanders to greater comfort obtainable by living in crowded communities and working as factory hire. Their ancestors were stalwart Scotch-Irish who, settling first in Pennsylvania, pushed onward into the wilderness seeking a place free from unjust taxation.

mods.abstract: The school bus makes two trips every morning and evening to bring those children who live too far in the mountains for them to walk. It is driven by a mountain boy, 22 years old, who goes to school here himself and is in the first year of high school. The children have learned a new song, borrowed from "I want to go back to Millikin" which they like to sing particularly well because it has something their bus in it. Here are the words: "We all like to go to Pi Phi School, Beneath the Smokies blue, Where all of the kids in the old school bus Are making an awful lot of fuss; We all like to go We all like to go To Pi Phi School."

titleInfo.title: This is one of the churches around Gatlinburg

mods.abstract: Sunday in the mountains is devoted fervidly to worship. When meeting is over, the congregation, separated during the week by difficultly traveled mountains, take advantage of the opportunity for conversation. Sometimes they stay at church all day and engage in what they call harp singing. Sunday School begins at 9:15 and church at 10:15. At 6:00 in the evening there is B.Y.P.U. for the young people, after which there is church again. Brother Lewis is the new preacher for the Baptist Church. Land has been purchased for a new parsonage which will soon be erected.
